What it means to be diagnosed Autistic.

The practical uses of an Autism diagnosis are perhaps questionable, but the personal validation it offers should not be understated.

ğŸ—“ï¸ 2024.03.28
â±ï¸ 4 minutes
ğŸ·ï¸ #autism

Photo by Mi Min onÂ Unsplash

I keep my inbox clean as a matter of principle, but I leave the email containing my diagnosis letter in my inbox as a reminder that I am, in fact, Autistic. That email is now a little over a month old and ironically ends with, â€œBest of luck.â€ I knew itâ€™s a common post-diagnosis experience to be whisked out the door and offered half-hearted reassurances like â€œgood luck,â€ but I didnâ€™t expect my own experience to be quite so literal.

We certainly have a long way to go in regard to post-diagnosis support and resources, but receiving my diagnosis has nonetheless been one of the most impactful events in my life. Iâ€™m still processing what it meansâ€”and I expect Iâ€™ll continue to do so years into the futureâ€”but for the first time in a very, very long time I finally feel like Iâ€™m making some real headway toward a brighter future.

In the time since my diagnosis, Iâ€™ve been asked by friends, family, and the doctor who diagnosed me various questions like: What does this mean for you? What does this do for you? What now? I suppose these are reasonable inquiries, especially if one doesnâ€™t understand Autism especially well in the first place. However, I havenâ€™t had a good answer to those questions. It takes me a while to process my emotions and discern what Iâ€™m even feeling in the first place (something called Alexithymia). I was confused: I felt relieved, but sad; excited, but terrified; sometimes I felt nothing at all.

Now, I feel like I have a pretty good answer: To be diagnosed Autistic is to be told that Iâ€™m valid. That I make sense. That itâ€™s okay to struggle sometimes.

When one experiences sensory and social difficulties no one else seems to; when one feels so alien to everyone else and no one understands them, the natural conclusion is there must be something wrong with them: Youâ€™re too sensitive. Youâ€™re too awkward. Youâ€™re too annoying. Youâ€™re too-

No, Iâ€™m just Autistic. Yes, I struggle with things other people donâ€™t, but I excel in areas other people donâ€™t, too. Iâ€™m very detail-oriented. I notice all sorts of things others never do, which makes me an excellent proof-reader. My intense interests allow me to view video games as something much greater than â€œchildrenâ€™s entertainment;â€ instead, as an ever-developing art form that offers experiences that simply cannot be replicated through any other medium. My unique perspective and communication style allows me to form deep connections with animals in a way that many people just canâ€™t. And while I have experienced a lot of pain and discomfort due to being chronically misunderstood, those experiences allow me to better understand and empathize with other people similar to me.

It turns out, the traits I had been despising and trying to pave-over my whole life were actually my best assets. I just needed to be told they made sense; that I wasnâ€™t broken.

I want to shout, â€œIâ€™m Autistic!â€ from the rooftops. I want to drone on-and-on and lecture about all Iâ€™ve learned about Autism and how it relates to me and explains why I am the way that I am. I want to be so visibly Autistic that no one would be surprised to learn that I am as such.

And yetâ€¦I wonâ€™t do those things. I wonâ€™t declare Iâ€™m Autistic to every person I meet, and Iâ€™ll try to refrain from lecturing about it. Iâ€™ll continue to mask, because, unfortunately it really is necessary in a lot of situations.

Maybe my workplace would react well to learning Iâ€™m Autistic. But maybe it wouldnâ€™t. Is it worth the risk? Probably not.

This is perhaps the most frustrating thing about diagnosis: once one has it, itâ€™s clear one has support needs, but getting accommodations for those needs is difficult and poses a lot of risks by merely inquiring about them.

One day, perhaps we will live in a world where neurodivergence is freely accepted, stimming isnâ€™t stigmatized, and neither are meltdowns or shutdowns. A world where sensory rooms are standard and no one will feel the need to be Secretly Autisticâ„¢.

Until that day, Iâ€™ll do what I can: Iâ€™ll stim a little more freely than before. While Iâ€™m certainly not comfortable stimming in public like I do in private, Iâ€™ve realized I can get away with a little more than I initially thought. Hopefully the sight of my ever-wiggly self will help others like me feel more comfortable to be themselves, in turn.

Iâ€™ll try to be more proactive in stating my needs. If I need information to be restated or presented differently, Iâ€™ll do so. If I need to leave a social gathering for a bit to recuperate, Iâ€™ll do so. And Iâ€™ll try not to beat myself up for doing those things.

To those that I feel safe enough with, Iâ€™ll disclose being Autistic. I donâ€™t want to hide this pivotal thing about myself. And through that disclosure, it allows the use of certain vocabulary to better express what Iâ€™m experiencing, so that hopefully we can start to finally understand each other.

And if they donâ€™t react favorably to that disclosure? Well, itâ€™s painful, but Iâ€™ll probably be happier without them in my life.

Life is still going to be hard. I know that. Unfortunately, diagnosis doesnâ€™t magically solve all oneâ€™s problems. Iâ€™m still me. Iâ€™m going to continue to struggle with sensory sensitivities, socializing is always going to be demanding and frequently intimidating, and Iâ€™m still going to have shutdowns. Iâ€™m just Autistic. And thatâ€™s okay.
